author: sky.cactus
content: Good live test of inactivity leaking!

author: sky.cactus
content: I would personally like to see it leak out and recover, just so we have a live/"production" instance of that happening that people can watch/review on public block explorers and whatnot.

author: ajsutton
content: We have seen it happen before a few times, but generally by the time it does all the block explorers have shutdown and no one cares anymore.

author: sky.cactus
content: We have seen inactivity leakouts on Ropsten before?

author: sky.cactus
content: If so, then apparently I am part of the problem (one of the no-one who doesn't care apparently).

author: ajsutton
content: Not on ropsten no, but on other testnets.

author: ajsutton
content: Sorry somehow that bit info got lost in my trying to form a coherent sentence. ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: I think seeing it on a widely used public testnet is a bit different because there are well established block explorers with long lifespans.  I could be wrong on this of course.

author: sky.cactus
content: Different from transient testnets that no one has ever cared about, Ropsten has people who use it regularly so I *feel* like this is different.

author: ajsutton
content:
It's happened on widely used testnets premerge before - Medalla most notably, but even things like Sepolia went through a very long period of non-finality before recovering after the vast majority of people stopped caring.
Not that I'm against it, but I'm not entirely sure what we're expecting to observe. The interesting bit is the long period of finality which we're already seeing, the recovery is pretty boring.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think I'm mostly interested in people talking about it more.  Since some people actually *use* Ropsten, including some users, there is value in them understanding and experiencing inactivity leaking and finality failure.  People who have dapps on Ropsten also will be forced to deal with the situation in their architecture/design.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think it will help core developers diagnose anything new, but since Ropsten failing to achieve finality will result in more people seeing/experiencing it, information/knowledge about it is more likely to reach more people.

author: sky.cactus
content: More like marketing/pr/education than testing.

author: m.kalinin
content: Yes, they will see `finalized` and `safe` blocks not moving for significant period of time which may stop their services from pulling new data from the blockchain. Medalla didn't have an execution layer when it was leaking, not sure about Sepolia though. I think let Ropsten leak and not finalize is a good chance to test dapps/services
